definitions.definition: to lift or move something to a higher level

examples.text: She raised the gun and fired.
He raised a hand in greeting.
She raised her eyes from her work.
He slowly raised his head up.

definitions.definition: to move somebody/something/yourself to a standing, sitting or vertical position

examples.text: Somehow we managed to raise her to her feet.
He raised himself up on one elbow.
The security man raised the barrier for me.

definitions.definition: to increase the amount or level of something

examples.text: to **raise prices/taxes**
We need to **raise** public **awareness** of the issue.
How can we raise standards in schools?
They raised their offer to $500.
Don't tell her about the job until you know for sure—we don't want to **raise her hopes** *(= make her hope too much)*.
I've never heard him even **raise his voice** *(= speak louder because he was angry)*.
They are threatening to raise fuel prices by 10%.
The government has promised not to raise taxes.
The campaign aims to raise awareness of domestic abuse.

definitions.definition: to bring or collect money or people together; to manage to get or form something

examples.text: We are **raising money** for charity.
They are holding a quiz to help **raise funds** for the club.
The event raised over £30 000 for cancer research.
He set about **raising an army**.
He needed to raise a loan in order to set up in business.
to help raise money for the repair of the stadium
The hospital is trying to raise funds for a new kidney machine.
The sale raised over £3 000 for charity.

definitions.definition: to mention something for people to discuss or somebody to deal with

examples.text: The book **raises** many important **questions**.
I'm glad you raised the subject of money.
I have **raised this issue** with the environmental health office.
Local residents have **raised concerns** about late-night noise.
You **raise** some interesting **points**.

definitions.definition: to cause or produce a feeling or reaction

examples.text: to raise doubts in people’s minds
The plans for the new development have raised angry protests from local residents.
It wasn't an easy audience but he **raised a laugh** with his joke.
It had been a difficult day but she managed to **raise a smile.**

definitions.definition: to make something happen or appear

examples.text: She **raised the alarm** when he failed to return home.
The horses' hooves raised a cloud of dust.

definitions.definition: to care for a child or young animal until it is able to take care of itself

examples.text: She **raised** five **children** on her own.
They were both raised in the South.
kids raised on a diet of hamburgers
They raised her (as) a Catholic.
I was **born and raised** a city boy.

definitions.definition: to breed (= keep and produce young from) particular farm animals; to grow particular crops

examples.text: Farmers cleared the land in order to raise cattle.
They raise wheat, soya beans and alfalfa on 460 acres.

definitions.definition: to end the limits on somebody/something

examples.text: to raise a blockade/ban/siege

definitions.definition: to contact somebody and speak to them by radio or phone

examples.text: We managed to raise him on his mobile.

definitions.definition: to make somebody who has died come to life again

examples.text: Christians believe that God raised Jesus from the dead.

definitions.definition: to make a higher bet than another player in a card game

examples.text: I'll raise you another hundred dollars.

definitions.definition: to multiply an amount by itself a particular number of times
definitions.sensetop: raise something to the power of something

examples.text: 3 raised to the power of 3 is 27 (= 3 × 3 × 3).

definitions.definition: to build something

examples.text: Our priority will be to raise a boundary wall and prevent trespassing.

definitions.definition: to create a document such as an invoice or a petition

examples.text: They have been raising a petition against the war.

definitions.definition: to make somebody angry

examples.text: Her controversial article is bound to raise hackles.

definitions.definition: to do nothing to help somebody

examples.text: The children never lift a finger to help around the house.

definitions.definition: to do nothing to help somebody

examples.text: The children never raised a finger to help around the house.

definitions.definition: to increase the level of something, especially your demands or the risks in a situation

examples.text: This year tournament organizers have upped the ante by offering record prize money for the top two teams.

definitions.definition: to set a new, higher standard of quality or performance

examples.text: The factory has raised the bar on productivity, food safety and quality.
This latest computer game raises the bar for interface design.
The awards go to people who have truly raised the bar.
Perhaps the new admission requirements raised the bar too high.

definitions.definition: to show that you think something is bad or are surprised by something

examples.text: Eyebrows were raised when he arrived without his wife.

definitions.definition: to hold up your glass and wish somebody happiness, good luck, etc. before you drink
to hit or threaten to hit somebody
to protest angrily, especially in a way that causes trouble for somebody
to produce or make somebody produce a lot of noise in a building, for example by shouting or cheering

examples.text: Their cheers raised the roof.

definitions.definition: to expect more/less from a situation

examples.text: If they can’t afford such a big house, they’ll just have to lower their sights a little.
After failing to get into university, he lowered his sights and got a job in a shop.

definitions.definition: to make somebody feel more cheerful or brave

examples.text: The sunny weather raised my spirits a little.

definitions.definition: to increase/decrease the amount of excitement, emotion, etc. in a situation

examples.text: His angry refusal to agree raised the temperature of the meeting.
The government tried to lower the political temperature by agreeing to some of the demands.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old Norse reisa; related to the verb rear.
